{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2987045,"name":null,"username":"_Cody","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/_/977dab/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-09T05:14:28.481Z","cooked":"

I installed all the packages for robotpy, but as I was downloading python for the roboRIO, I ran into the error “C:\Users\hinak\Desktop\FirstProgram22\FirstProgram22\Scripts\python.exe: No module named robotpy-installer”.

Screenshot (148)1920×1080 205 KB
!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2022-01-09T05:14:28.481Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":112,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":595.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":399156,"topic_slug":"robotpy-module-not-found","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/b/3/b39570655fe4db3b54258f203430e1b7964245b2.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50337,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robotpy-module-not-found/399156/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":2987062,"name":"","username":"Vasista","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-09T05:46:22.462Z","cooked":"

Python modules called from the terminal have they’re hyphens replaced with underscores. So, you would use py -m robotpy_installer instead.

note: The 2022 version of robotpy has not yet been released.

While trying to download python for the roboRIO using robotpy-installer, we ran into the error “urllib.error.URLError: <urlopen error [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: certificate has expired (_ssl.c:1129)>”

Screenshot (150)1920×1080 270 KB
!

I tried using the underscore instead, but still got the certificate error mentioned in my reply. I’m using 2021 to test our equipment. Thank you for the quick response.

Others have faced the SSL expired certificate problem (though not exactly the same as yours). Here’s a thread: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/expired-ssl-certificate/395329/6
Hope it helps

Does it say what file it’s trying to download? The certificate for https://www.tortall.net/ is not expired, so it should work. Are you on a school network?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2022-01-09T21:09:27.600Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":38,"readers_count":37,"score":27.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":399156,"topic_slug":"robotpy-module-not-found","display_username":"Dustin Spicuzza","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50337,"username":"_Cody","name":null,"avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/_/977dab/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer"},"post_url":"/t/robotpy-module-not-found/399156/9","custom_user_title":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2987553,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-09T21:11:09.008Z","cooked":"

Also, you might try upgrading certifi, since python will sometimes use that for certificates?

py -3 -m pip install -U certifi

If that fixes it, please let me know, and we can fix it for the next person who runs into it (tracking it at https://github.com/robotpy/robotpy-installer/issues/57).

What’s the output of py -3 -m pip list?

… It’ll be easier for everyone if you just copy/paste the text instead of taking a screenshot. You can surround the text with

```
text I want to show
```

So that it doesn’t reformat it

Heh, looks fine to me, this is quite weird. It’s likely that the Let’s Encrypt root certificate hasn’t been updated on your system for some reason… though I thought python used certifi by default now?

I don’t use Windows at all these days, but according to this SO post maybe try browsing to https://www.tortall.net to get the certificate in your certificate cache and then try again?

Well, that’s not really a programming thing per se, it’s one of those things that should ‘just work’.

Does browsing to https://www.tortall.net on your Microsoft browser (IE, Edge) have a certificate error also? I’m not sure if other browsers use the system certificate store or not.

… for giggles, if you previously used a non-microsoft browser to go to tortall.net, then try running the robotpy-installer command again.
